data.title: Use multiple editors rather than one per pane
data.body:
Depends on #946 

Gets rid of the `viewsByClassName` approach from the pane. Just uses `viewsByItem`.

data.title: Fix hidden input placement
data.body:
In the speedup work i've been doing, I changed the `editor.hiddenInput` to use the cursorView's style attribute rather than `$.offset()` because it is much faster. However the hiddenInput and the cursorView had different parents, so was placing the hidden input in the wrong spot. Occasionally the hiddenInput would get focus and scroll the `scrollView` which blanks the editor window.

Soooo, this moves the hiddenInput to the underlayer, and places it in the visible area when it's focused, keeping the speedup and mitigating the editor blank screen.

data.title: Auto-save untitled buffers
data.body:
One feature I love of an increasing number of Mac OSX Lion and above apps is the auto-saving of untitled buffers.  If I quit an app that supports this behavior and re-open it, even untitled buffers (never explicitly named and saved) are restored. This lets me have greater confidence about using these apps as "clipboards," knowing that even if I crash or accidentally close the app, I'll have some reasonably up-to-date copy of the file restored.

Sublime is the front-of-mind example for this in my daily workflow.

data.title: Use current window size for new window size
data.body:
New windows now open at the same size as the current window and centered.

The default default size has also be increased from 800 x 600 to 1024 x the total screen height.

Feedback welcome

data.title: Partially render the gutter when possible
data.body:
The gutter rendering is the last piece in the editor rendering :racehorse: puzzle. Most of the time we just need to add or remove few lines form the ends, but currently all the line numbers are re-rendered all the time

This pull detects the case when we can partially render, and does just that. 

Scrolling is smoother! Less work is being done when a newline is added or a line is removed! It's much better.

data.title: Open files asyncronously
data.body:
The goal of this PR is to make opening large files possible. It adds an async pathway to open a file but keeps the existing synchronous path around for tests and compatibility.

The slow part now appears to be telepath. When opening a 1 meg file this is the profile:
![file-1m txt - _users_corey_desktop_files-1](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/596/1285198/a9085faa-2fa3-11e3-99b6-513eb8865def.jpg)

If you try and open a 5 meg file Atom will still crash because it runs out of memory. I'm not sure the proper way forward here. We either need to make telepath work well with large files, or we need to make large files not use telepath.

data.title: Add API to open urls
data.body:
Packages can now register a `urlMain` that will be loaded as the bootstrap script for new windows spawned from opening urls.

The basic idea is that the host of the url being opened is mapped to the package name.  If that package has a `urlMain` registered then a new window is created with that `urlMain` as the bootstrap script.

So `atom://collaboration/12345` would load the collaboration package's `./lib/bootstrap.coffee` when opened.

The goal of this PR is to get collaboration URLs working again without Atom core knowing about the collaboration package.

See https://github.com/atom/collaboration/pull/14 for a reference implementation.

data.title: Add a simple gutter api for adding/removing classes
data.body:
A current point of slowdown is the gutter handling done by the git-diff and bookmarks modules. The profiler tells me that most time is spent in `jQuery.find` trying to match attributes.

I want to have an api for changing classes on gutter rows that make it easy to do the right thing. 

I've removed the `lineNumber` attribute and opted instead for a `line-number-[0-9+]` approach. Then I use the nodes directly. 

Nearing finish.

data.title: Issues opening a sub project in a separate atom window
data.body:
The github repo is huge, and I have all the vendored gems hidden from Atom.  Occasionally I'd like to be able to open a specific gem up.  Unfortunately, nothing happens if I already have an atom project open.  Is there something we can do here:

To replicate:
1. Open the github repository
   - `$ atom .`
2. If it's bootstrapped, try to open a gem:
   - `$ script/bootstrap`
   - `$ cd vendor/gems/1.9.3/ruby/1.9.1/gems/marginalia-1.1.2`
   - `$ atom .`

Edit: If I close the github atom window, an empty atom window pops up when I try to open the vendored gem directory.

data.title: Link to line of code or file on github.com from editor
data.body:
When someone asks a question like "Where is the test for this code?" in chat, I leave Atom, find the browser window, open a tab, type in the repository url, push `t` to open the file finder, click on the file, shift-select the lines of code, copy the url, and paste it into the chat window.  This process actually happens several times a day, and it's kind of a bummer.

What I'd like to do, is see that question in chat, navigate to the file and method in Atom (which I'm almost always using anyways, and Atom's navigation is way faster than the browser), select the code and get a link to github.com, with some keyboard shortcut or menu item, and paste it into chat.

What do you guys think?

data.title: Create repos for converted TextMate bundles
data.body:
Currently we use the [bundle2package](https://github.com/atom/bundle2package) tool to convert textmate bundles on the fly to atom packages and then just publish them all to apm.  This was nice as it let us pull them out of submodules and gave us 150+ packages for all types of languages.

The more I think about it the more I think we actually want to have each of the bundles we ship with as a full-fledged repo until the atom org that we maintain, version, publish, etc.
### Main Reasons
- **Build community**: On day 1 of Atom launching if someone wants to fix a grammar bug or add a new snippet, we want them to do in a repo under the atom org. We don't want to tell them "Go to the TextMate repo, update a plist, open a PR, and let us know when they accept it and we'll reconvert it and publish it".
- **TextMate bundles are not semantically versioned**: Well actually they aren't  really versioned at all, they aren't tagged, they don't have changelogs.  So when we rebuild them we have to go through the commit log, look for shady things, do some testing, and regressions still slip through.  We have no way of knowing when a bundle is "ready" for release and should be updated.
- **atom/javascript-support**: As we level up snippets, grammars, commands, etc. over time we want to do it on our terms and we want it always to be under our org. as we evolve our language support in future versions.  We want people to star and watch these repos if they are interested in making language `X` better in Atom.
### Proposal
1. Create a repo for each TextMate bundle currently listed in the `package.json` file (currently 31) with the generated package.
2. Delete out all folders/files for things we don't support so they are clean and consistent.
3. Add a `README.md` to each repo explaining that they were originally generated from a TextMate bundle and that repo's location.
4. Add a command to `bundle2package` that regenerates a TextMate bundle.  This would allow us to still pull in changes from the TextMate repos but always have diffs that are in JSON and that we selectively can commit or not ignore.

data.title: Use Travis CI for Atom packages
data.body:
We want to encourage development best practices for our 3rd party package authors. Currently we don't CI our Atom packages, however we should now that we have `apm test`.  

While we could use janky internally, I talked with @kevinsawicki and we think it would be better to use Travis so that when things become public we have an easily replicable CI setup for our 3rd party package developers to use.

It should be fairly straightforward once we have a private account on travis-ci.com. I think we just need to set something like this each package's `.travis.yml`.

```
language: objective-c
before_script: <download/install atom>
script: open -a Atom --args -f -t --spec-directory `pwd`
```
### Useful links
- I found this when I was researching caching assets
  https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-build/pull/138

data.title: Always launch Atom as a separate process (when just running specs)
data.body:
Previously, if you attempted to run a spec window and an Atom process was already running it would run the specs in the already running process which prevented the spec output from being seen.

This also updates the bundled version of apm to include `apm test`.

data.title: Only reload active package stylesheets
data.body:
During a little startup profiling I noticed that all package stylesheets were being loaded twice.

This change fixes that but I just wanted to check with @benogle  and @mcolyer to double check that this is okay to do. Stylesheets aren't loaded until packages are activated as of pull #880 so this seemed safe to me.

data.body: Previously this involved finding/creating/removing and style tag which took up some time in specs and this seemed functionally equivalent.
